                         const LodePNGDecompressSettings* settings);
736
737
/*
738
Decompresses Zlib data. Reallocates the out buffer and appends the data. The
739
data must be according to the zlib specification.
740
Either, *out must be NULL and *outsize must be 0, or, *out must be a valid
741
buffer and *outsize its size in bytes. out must be freed by user after usage.
742
*/
743
unsigned lodepng_zlib_decompress(unsigned char** out, size_t* outsize,
744
                                 const unsigned char* in, size_t insize,
745
                                 const LodePNGDecompressSettings* settings);
746
#endif /*LODEPNG_COMPILE_DECODER*/
747
748
#ifdef LODEPNG_COMPILE_ENCODER
749
/*
750
Compresses data with Zlib. Reallocates the out buffer and appends the data.
751
Zlib adds a small header and trailer around the deflate data.
752
The data is output in the format of the zlib specification.
753
Either, *out must be NULL and *outsize must be 0, or, *out must be a valid
754
buffer and *outsize its size in bytes. out must be freed by user after usage.
755
*/
756
unsigned lodepng_zlib_compress(unsigned char** out, size_t* outsize,
757
                               const unsigned char* in, size_t insize,
758
                               const LodePNGCompressSettings* settings);
759
760
/*
761
Find length-limited Huffman code for given frequencies. This function is in the
762
public interface only for tests, it's used internally by lodepng_deflate.
763
*/
764
unsigned lodepng_huffman_code_lengths(unsigned* lengths, const unsigned* frequencies,
765
                                      size_t numcodes, unsigned maxbitlen);
766
767
/*Compress a buffer with deflate. See RFC 1951. Out buffer must be freed after use.*/
768
unsigned lodepng_deflate(unsigned char** out, size_t* outsize,
769
                         const unsigned char* in, size_t insize,
770
                         const LodePNGCompressSettings* settings);
771
772
#endif /*LODEPNG_COMPILE_ENCODER*/
773
#endif /*LODEPNG_COMPILE_ZLIB*/
774
775
#ifdef LODEPNG_COMPILE_DISK
776
/*
777
Load a file from disk into buffer. The function allocates the out buffer, and
778
after usage you should free it.
779
out: output parameter, contains pointer to loaded buffer.
780
outsize: output parameter, size of the allocated out buffer
781
filename: the path to the file to load
782
return value: error code (0 means ok)
783
*/
784
unsigned lodepng_load_file(unsigned char** out, size_t* outsize, const char* filename);
785
786
/*
787
Save a file from buffer to disk. Warning, if it exists, this function overwrites
788
the file without warning!
789
buffer: the buffer to write
790
buffersize: size of the buffer to write
791
filename: the path to the file to save to
792
return value: error code (0 means ok)
793
*/
794
unsigned lodepng_save_file(const unsigned char* buffer, size_t buffersize, const char* filename);
795
#endif /*LODEPNG_COMPILE_DISK*/
796
797
#ifdef LODEPNG_COMPILE_CPP
798
/* The LodePNG C++ wrapper uses std::vectors instead of manually allocated memory buffers. */
799
namespace lodepng
800
{
801
#ifdef LODEPNG_COMPILE_PNG
802
class State : public LodePNGState
803
{
804
  public:
805
    State();
806
    State(const State& other);
807
    virtual ~State();
808
    State& operator=(const State& other);
809
};
810
811
#ifdef LODEPNG_COMPILE_DECODER
812
/* Same as other lodepng::decode, but using a State for more settings and information. */
813
unsigned decode(std::vector<unsigned char>& out, unsigned& w, unsigned& h,
814
                State& state,
815
                const unsigned char* in, size_t insize);
816
unsigned decode(std::vector<unsigned char>& out, unsigned& w, unsigned& h,
817
                State& state,
818
                const std::vector<unsigned char>& in);
819
#endif /*LODEPNG_COMPILE_DECODER*/
820
821
#ifdef LODEPNG_COMPILE_ENCODER
822
/* Same as other lodepng::encode, but using a State for more settings and information. */
823
unsigned encode(std::vector<unsigned char>& out,
824
                const unsigned char* in, unsigned w, unsigned h,
825
                State& state);
826
unsigned encode(std::vector<unsigned char>& out,
827
                const std::vector<unsigned char>& in, unsigned w, unsigned h,
828
                State& state);
829
#endif /*LODEPNG_COMPILE_ENCODER*/
830
831
#ifdef LODEPNG_COMPILE_DISK
832
/*
833
Load a file from disk into an std::vector.
834
return value: error code (0 means ok)
835
*/
836
unsigned load_file(std::vector<unsigned char>& buffer, const std::string& filename);
837
838
/*
839
Save the binary data in an std::vector to a file on disk. The file is overwritten
840
without warning.
841
*/
842
unsigned save_file(const std::vector<unsigned char>& buffer, const std::string& filename);
843
#endif /* LODEPNG_COMPILE_DISK */
844
#endif /* LODEPNG_COMPILE_PNG */
845
846
#ifdef LODEPNG_COMPILE_ZLIB
847
#ifdef LODEPNG_COMPILE_DECODER
848
/* Zlib-decompress an unsigned char buffer */
849
unsigned decompress(std::vector<unsigned char>& out, const unsigned char* in, size_t insize,
850
                    const LodePNGDecompressSettings& settings = lodepng_default_decompress_settings);
851
852
/* Zlib-decompress an std::vector */
853
unsigned decompress(std::vector<unsigned char>& out, const std::vector<unsigned char>& in,
854
                    const LodePNGDecompressSettings& settings = lodepng_default_decompress_settings);
855
#endif /* LODEPNG_COMPILE_DECODER */
856
857
#ifdef LODEPNG_COMPILE_ENCODER
858
/* Zlib-compress an unsigned char buffer */
859
unsigned compress(std::vector<unsigned char>& out, const unsigned char* in, size_t insize,
860
                  const LodePNGCompressSettings& settings = lodepng_default_compress_settings);
861
862
/* Zlib-compress an std::vector */
863
unsigned compress(std::vector<unsigned char>& out, const std::vector<unsigned char>& in,
864
                  const LodePNGCompressSettings& settings = lodepng_default_compress_settings);
865
#endif /* LODEPNG_COMPILE_ENCODER */
866
#endif /* LODEPNG_COMPILE_ZLIB */
867
} /* namespace lodepng */
868
#endif /*LODEPNG_COMPILE_CPP*/
869
870
/*
871
TODO:
872
[.] test if there are no memory leaks or security exploits - done a lot but needs to be checked often
873
[.] check compatibility with various compilers  - done but needs to be redone for every newer version
874
[X] converting color to 16-bit per channel types
875
[ ] read all public PNG chunk types (but never let the color profile and gamma ones touch RGB values)
876
[ ] make sure encoder generates no chunks with size > (2^31)-1
877
[ ] partial decoding (stream processing)
878
[X] let the "isFullyOpaque" function check color keys and transparent palettes too
879
[X] better name for the variables "codes", "codesD", "codelengthcodes", "clcl" and "lldl"
880
[ ] don't stop decoding on errors like 69, 57, 58 (make warnings)
881
[ ] make warnings like: oob palette, checksum fail, data after iend, wrong/unknown crit chunk, no null terminator in text, ...
882
[ ] let the C++ wrapper catch exceptions coming from the standard library and return LodePNG error codes
883
[ ] allow user to provide custom color conversion functions, e.g. for premultiplied alpha, padding bits or not, ...
884
[ ] allow user to give data (void*) to custom allocator
885
*/
886
887
#endif /*LODEPNG_H inclusion guard*/
888
889
/*
890
LodePNG Documentation
891
---------------------
892
0. table of contents
893
--------------------
894
  1. about
895
   1.1. supported features
896
   1.2. features not supported
897
  2. C and C++ version
898
  3. security
899
  4. decoding
900
  5. encoding
901
  6. color conversions
902
    6.1. PNG color types
903
    6.2. color conversions
904
    6.3. padding bits
905
    6.4. A note about 16-bits per channel and endianness
906
  7. error values
907
  8. chunks and PNG editing
908
  9. compiler support
909
  10. examples
910
   10.1. decoder C++ example
911
   10.2. decoder C example
912
  11. state settings reference
913
  12. changes
914
  13. contact information
915
1. about
916
--------
917
PNG is a file format to store raster images losslessly with good compression,
918
supporting different color types and alpha channel.
919
LodePNG is a PNG codec according to the Portable Network Graphics (PNG)
920
Specification (Second Edition) - W3C Recommendation 10 November 2003.
921
The specifications used are:
922
*) Portable Network Graphics (PNG) Specification (Second Edition):
923
     http://www.w3.org/TR/2003/REC-PNG-20031110
924
*) RFC 1950 ZLIB Compressed Data Format version 3.3:
925
     http://www.gzip.org/zlib/rfc-zlib.html
926
*) RFC 1951 DEFLATE Compressed Data Format Specification ver 1.3:
927
     http://www.gzip.org/zlib/rfc-deflate.html
928
The most recent version of LodePNG can currently be found at
929
http://lodev.org/lodepng/
930
LodePNG works both in C (ISO C90) and C++, with a C++ wrapper that adds
931
extra functionality.
932
LodePNG exists out of two files:
933
-lodepng.h: the header file for both C and C++
934
-lodepng.c(pp): give it the name lodepng.c or lodepng.cpp (or .cc) depending on your usage
935
If you want to start using LodePNG right away without reading this doc, get the
936
examples from the LodePNG website to see how to use it in code, or check the
937
smaller examples in chapter 13 here.
938
LodePNG is simple but only supports the basic requirements. To achieve
939
simplicity, the following design choices were made: There are no dependencies
940
on any external library. There are functions to decode and encode a PNG with
941
a single function call, and extended versions of these functions taking a
942
LodePNGState struct allowing to specify or get more information. By default
943
the colors of the raw image are always RGB or RGBA, no matter what color type
944
the PNG file uses. To read and write files, there are simple functions to
945
convert the files to/from buffers in memory.
946
This all makes LodePNG suitable for loading textures in games, demos and small
947
programs, ... It's less suitable for full fledged image editors, loading PNGs
948
over network (it requires all the image data to be available before decoding can
949
begin), life-critical systems, ...
950
1.1. supported features
951
-----------------------
952
The following features are supported by the decoder:
953
*) decoding of PNGs with any color type, bit depth and interlace mode, to a 24- or 32-bit color raw image,
954
   or the same color type as the PNG
955
*) encoding of PNGs, from any raw image to 24- or 32-bit color, or the same color type as the raw image
956
*) Adam7 interlace and deinterlace for any color type
957
*) loading the image from harddisk or decoding it from a buffer from other sources than harddisk
958
*) support for alpha channels, including RGBA color model, translucent palettes and color keying
959
*) zlib decompression (inflate)
960
*) zlib compression (deflate)
961
*) CRC32 and ADLER32 checksums
962
*) handling of unknown chunks, allowing making a PNG editor that stores custom and unknown chunks.
963
*) the following chunks are supported (generated/interpreted) by both encoder and decoder:
964
    IHDR: header information
965
    PLTE: color palette
966
    IDAT: pixel data
967
    IEND: the final chunk
968
    tRNS: transparency for palettized images
969
    tEXt: textual information
970
    zTXt: compressed textual information
971
    iTXt: international textual information
972
    bKGD: suggested background color
973
    pHYs: physical dimensions
974
    tIME: modification time
975
1.2. features not supported
976
---------------------------
977
The following features are _not_ supported:
978
*) some features needed to make a conformant PNG-Editor might be still missing.
979
*) partial loading/stream processing. All data must be available and is processed in one call.
980
*) The following public chunks are not supported but treated as unknown chunks by LodePNG
981
    cHRM, gAMA, iCCP, sRGB, sBIT, hIST, sPLT
982
   Some of these are not supported on purpose: LodePNG wants to provide the RGB values
983
   stored in the pixels, not values modified by system dependent gamma or color models.
984
 
985
2. C and C++ version
986
--------------------
987
The C version uses buffers allocated with alloc that you need to free()
988
yourself. You need to use init and cleanup functions for each struct whenever
989
using a struct from the C version to avoid exploits and memory leaks.
990
The C++ version has extra functions with std::vectors in the interface and the
991
lodepng::State class which is a LodePNGState with constructor and destructor.
992
These files work without modification for both C and C++ compilers because all
993
the additional C++ code is in "#ifdef __cplusplus" blocks that make C-compilers
994
ignore it, and the C code is made to compile both with strict ISO C90 and C++.
995
To use the C++ version, you need to rename the source file to lodepng.cpp
996
(instead of lodepng.c), and compile it with a C++ compiler.
997
To use the C version, you need to rename the source file to lodepng.c (instead
998
of lodepng.cpp), and compile it with a C compiler.
999
3. Security
1000
-----------
1001
Even if carefully designed, it's always possible that LodePNG contains possible
1002
exploits. If you discover one, please let me know, and it will be fixed.
1003
When using LodePNG, care has to be taken with the C version of LodePNG, as well
1004
as the C-style structs when working with C++. The following conventions are used
1005
for all C-style structs:
1006
-if a struct has a corresponding init function, always call the init function when making a new one
1007
-if a struct has a corresponding cleanup function, call it before the struct disappears to avoid memory leaks
1008
-if a struct has a corresponding copy function, use the copy function instead of "=".
1009
 The destination must also be inited already.
1010
4. Decoding
1011
-----------
1012
Decoding converts a PNG compressed image to a raw pixel buffer.
1013
Most documentation on using the decoder is at its declarations in the header
1014
above. For C, simple decoding can be done with functions such as
1015
lodepng_decode32, and more advanced decoding can be done with the struct
1016
LodePNGState and lodepng_decode. For C++, all decoding can be done with the
1017
various lodepng::decode functions, and lodepng::State can be used for advanced
1018
features.
1019
When using the LodePNGState, it uses the following fields for decoding:
1020
*) LodePNGInfo info_png: it stores extra information about the PNG (the input) in here
1021
*) LodePNGColorMode info_raw: here you can say what color mode of the raw image (the output) you want to get
1022
*) LodePNGDecoderSettings decoder: you can specify a few extra settings for the decoder to use
1023
LodePNGInfo info_png
1024
--------------------
1025
After decoding, this contains extra information of the PNG image, except the actual
1026
pixels, width and height because these are already gotten directly from the decoder
1027
functions.
1028
It contains for example the original color type of the PNG image, text comments,
1029
suggested background color, etc... More details about the LodePNGInfo struct are
1030
at its declaration documentation.
1031
LodePNGColorMode info_raw
1032
-------------------------
1033
When decoding, here you can specify which color type you want
1034
the resulting raw image to be. If this is different from the colortype of the
1035
PNG, then the decoder will automatically convert the result. This conversion
1036
always works, except if you want it to convert a color PNG to greyscale or to
1037
a palette with missing colors.
1038
By default, 32-bit color is used for the result.
1039
LodePNGDecoderSettings decoder
1040
------------------------------
1041
The settings can be used to ignore the errors created by invalid CRC and Adler32
1042
chunks, and to disable the decoding of tEXt chunks.
1043
There's also a setting color_convert, true by default. If false, no conversion
1044
is done, the resulting data will be as it was in the PNG (after decompression)
1045
and you'll have to puzzle the colors of the pixels together yourself using the
1046
color type information in the LodePNGInfo.
1047
5. Encoding
1048
-----------
1049
Encoding converts a raw pixel buffer to a PNG compressed image.
1050
Most documentation on using the encoder is at its declarations in the header
1051
above. For C, simple encoding can be done with functions such as
1052
lodepng_encode32, and more advanced decoding can be done with the struct
1053
LodePNGState and lodepng_encode. For C++, all encoding can be done with the
1054
various lodepng::encode functions, and lodepng::State can be used for advanced
1055
features.
1056
Like the decoder, the encoder can also give errors. However it gives less errors
1057
since the encoder input is trusted, the decoder input (a PNG image that could
1058
be forged by anyone) is not trusted.
1059
When using the LodePNGState, it uses the following fields for encoding:
1060
*) LodePNGInfo info_png: here you specify how you want the PNG (the output) to be.
1061
*) LodePNGColorMode info_raw: here you say what color type of the raw image (the input) has
1062
*) LodePNGEncoderSettings encoder: you can specify a few settings for the encoder to use
1063
LodePNGInfo info_png
1064
--------------------
1065
When encoding, you use this the opposite way as when decoding: for encoding,
1066
you fill in the values you want the PNG to have before encoding. By default it's
1067
not needed to specify a color type for the PNG since it's automatically chosen,
1068
but it's possible to choose it yourself given the right settings.
1069
The encoder will not always exactly match the LodePNGInfo struct you give,
1070
it tries as close as possible. Some things are ignored by the encoder. The
1071
encoder uses, for example, the following settings from it when applicable:
1072
colortype and bitdepth, text chunks, time chunk, the color key, the palette, the
1073
background color, the interlace method, unknown chunks, ...
1074
When encoding to a PNG with colortype 3, the encoder will generate a PLTE chunk.
1075
If the palette contains any colors for which the alpha channel is not 255 (so
1076
there are translucent colors in the palette), it'll add a tRNS chunk.
1077
LodePNGColorMode info_raw
1078
-------------------------
1079
You specify the color type of the raw image that you give to the input here,
1080
including a possible transparent color key and palette you happen to be using in
1081
your raw image data.
1082
By default, 32-bit color is assumed, meaning your input has to be in RGBA
1083
format with 4 bytes (unsigned chars) per pixel.
1084
LodePNGEncoderSettings encoder
1085
------------------------------
1086
The following settings are supported (some are in sub-structs):
1087
*) auto_convert: when this option is enabled, the encoder will
1088
automatically choose the smallest possible color mode (including color key) that
1089
can encode the colors of all pixels without information loss.
1090
*) btype: the block type for LZ77. 0 = uncompressed, 1 = fixed huffman tree,
1091
   2 = dynamic huffman tree (best compression). Should be 2 for proper
1092
   compression.
1093
*) use_lz77: whether or not to use LZ77 for compressed block types. Should be
1094
   true for proper compression.
1095
*) windowsize: the window size used by the LZ77 encoder (1 - 32768). Has value
1096
   2048 by default, but can be set to 32768 for better, but slow, compression.
1097
*) force_palette: if colortype is 2 or 6, you can make the encoder write a PLTE
1098
   chunk if force_palette is true. This can used as suggested palette to convert
1099
   to by viewers that don't support more than 256 colors (if those still exist)
1100
*) add_id: add text chunk "Encoder: LodePNG <version>" to the image.
1101
*) text_compression: default 1. If 1, it'll store texts as zTXt instead of tEXt chunks.
1102
  zTXt chunks use zlib compression on the text. This gives a smaller result on
1103
  large texts but a larger result on small texts (such as a single program name).
1104
  It's all tEXt or all zTXt though, there's no separate setting per text yet.
1105
6. color conversions
1106
--------------------
1107
An important thing to note about LodePNG, is that the color type of the PNG, and
1108
the color type of the raw image, are completely independent. By default, when
1109
you decode a PNG, you get the result as a raw image in the color type you want,
1110
no matter whether the PNG was encoded with a palette, greyscale or RGBA color.
1111
And if you encode an image, by default LodePNG will automatically choose the PNG
1112
color type that gives good compression based on the values of colors and amount
1113
of colors in the image. It can be configured to let you control it instead as
1114
well, though.
1115
To be able to do this, LodePNG does conversions from one color mode to another.
1116
It can convert from almost any color type to any other color type, except the
1117
following conversions: RGB to greyscale is not supported, and converting to a
1118
palette when the palette doesn't have a required color is not supported. This is
1119
not supported on purpose: this is information loss which requires a color
1120
reduction algorithm that is beyong the scope of a PNG encoder (yes, RGB to grey
1121
is easy, but there are multiple ways if you want to give some channels more
1122
weight).
1123
By default, when decoding, you get the raw image in 32-bit RGBA or 24-bit RGB
1124
color, no matter what color type the PNG has. And by default when encoding,
1125
LodePNG automatically picks the best color model for the output PNG, and expects
1126
the input image to be 32-bit RGBA or 24-bit RGB. So, unless you want to control
1127
the color format of the images yourself, you can skip this chapter.
1128
6.1. PNG color types
1129
--------------------
1130
A PNG image can have many color types, ranging from 1-bit color to 64-bit color,
1131
as well as palettized color modes. After the zlib decompression and unfiltering
1132
in the PNG image is done, the raw pixel data will have that color type and thus
1133
a certain amount of bits per pixel. If you want the output raw image after
1134
decoding to have another color type, a conversion is done by LodePNG.
1135
The PNG specification gives the following color types:
1136
0: greyscale, bit depths 1, 2, 4, 8, 16
1137
2: RGB, bit depths 8 and 16
1138
3: palette, bit depths 1, 2, 4 and 8
1139
4: greyscale with alpha, bit depths 8 and 16
1140
6: RGBA, bit depths 8 and 16
1141
Bit depth is the amount of bits per pixel per color channel. So the total amount
1142
of bits per pixel is: amount of channels * bitdepth.
1143
6.2. color conversions
1144
----------------------
1145
As explained in the sections about the encoder and decoder, you can specify
1146
color types and bit depths in info_png and info_raw to change the default
1147
behaviour.
1148
If, when decoding, you want the raw image to be something else than the default,
1149
you need to set the color type and bit depth you want in the LodePNGColorMode,
1150
or the parameters colortype and bitdepth of the simple decoding function.
1151
If, when encoding, you use another color type than the default in the raw input
1152
image, you need to specify its color type and bit depth in the LodePNGColorMode
1153
of the raw image, or use the parameters colortype and bitdepth of the simple
1154
encoding function.
1155
If, when encoding, you don't want LodePNG to choose the output PNG color type
1156
but control it yourself, you need to set auto_convert in the encoder settings
1157
to false, and specify the color type you want in the LodePNGInfo of the
1158
encoder (including palette: it can generate a palette if auto_convert is true,
1159
otherwise not).
1160
If the input and output color type differ (whether user chosen or auto chosen),
1161
LodePNG will do a color conversion, which follows the rules below, and may
1162
sometimes result in an error.
1163
To avoid some confusion:
1164
-the decoder converts from PNG to raw image
1165
-the encoder converts from raw image to PNG
1166
-the colortype and bitdepth in LodePNGColorMode info_raw, are those of the raw image
1167
-the colortype and bitdepth in the color field of LodePNGInfo info_png, are those of the PNG
1168
-when encoding, the color type in LodePNGInfo is ignored if auto_convert
1169
 is enabled, it is automatically generated instead
1170
-when decoding, the color type in LodePNGInfo is set by the decoder to that of the original
1171
 PNG image, but it can be ignored since the raw image has the color type you requested instead
1172
-if the color type of the LodePNGColorMode and PNG image aren't the same, a conversion
1173
 between the color types is done if the color types are supported. If it is not
1174
 supported, an error is returned. If the types are the same, no conversion is done.
1175
-even though some conversions aren't supported, LodePNG supports loading PNGs from any
1176
 colortype and saving PNGs to any colortype, sometimes it just requires preparing
1177
 the raw image correctly before encoding.
1178
-both encoder and decoder use the same color converter.
1179
Non supported color conversions:
1180
-color to greyscale: no error is thrown, but the result will look ugly because
1181
only the red channel is taken
1182
-anything to palette when that palette does not have that color in it: in this
1183
case an error is thrown
1184
Supported color conversions:
1185
-anything to 8-bit RGB, 8-bit RGBA, 16-bit RGB, 16-bit RGBA
1186
-any grey or grey+alpha, to grey or grey+alpha
1187
-anything to a palette, as long as the palette has the requested colors in it
1188
-removing alpha channel
1189
-higher to smaller bitdepth, and vice versa
1190
If you want no color conversion to be done (e.g. for speed or control):
1191
-In the encoder, you can make it save a PNG with any color type by giving the
1192
raw color mode and LodePNGInfo the same color mode, and setting auto_convert to
1193
false.
1194
-In the decoder, you can make it store the pixel data in the same color type
1195
as the PNG has, by setting the color_convert setting to false. Settings in
1196
info_raw are then ignored.
1197
The function lodepng_convert does the color conversion. It is available in the
1198
interface but normally isn't needed since the encoder and decoder already call
1199
it.
1200
6.3. padding bits
1201
-----------------
1202
In the PNG file format, if a less than 8-bit per pixel color type is used and the scanlines
1203
have a bit amount that isn't a multiple of 8, then padding bits are used so that each
1204
scanline starts at a fresh byte. But that is NOT true for the LodePNG raw input and output.
1205
The raw input image you give to the encoder, and the raw output image you get from the decoder
1206
will NOT have these padding bits, e.g. in the case of a 1-bit image with a width
1207
of 7 pixels, the first pixel of the second scanline will the the 8th bit of the first byte,
1208
not the first bit of a new byte.
1209
6.4. A note about 16-bits per channel and endianness
1210
----------------------------------------------------
1211
LodePNG uses unsigned char arrays for 16-bit per channel colors too, just like
1212
for any other color format. The 16-bit values are stored in big endian (most
1213
significant byte first) in these arrays. This is the opposite order of the
1214
little endian used by x86 CPU's.
1215
LodePNG always uses big endian because the PNG file format does so internally.
1216
Conversions to other formats than PNG uses internally are not supported by
1217
LodePNG on purpose, there are myriads of formats, including endianness of 16-bit
1218
colors, the order in which you store R, G, B and A, and so on. Supporting and
1219
converting to/from all that is outside the scope of LodePNG.
1220
This may mean that, depending on your use case, you may want to convert the big
1221
endian output of LodePNG to little endian with a for loop. This is certainly not
1222
always needed, many applications and libraries support big endian 16-bit colors
1223
anyway, but it means you cannot simply cast the unsigned char* buffer to an
1224
unsigned short* buffer on x86 CPUs.
1225
7. error values
1226
---------------
1227
All functions in LodePNG that return an error code, return 0 if everything went
1228
OK, or a non-zero code if there was an error.
1229
The meaning of the LodePNG error values can be retrieved with the function
1230
lodepng_error_text: given the numerical error code, it returns a description
1231
of the error in English as a string.
1232
Check the implementation of lodepng_error_text to see the meaning of each code.
1233
8. chunks and PNG editing
1234
-------------------------
1235
If you want to add extra chunks to a PNG you encode, or use LodePNG for a PNG
1236
editor that should follow the rules about handling of unknown chunks, or if your
1237
program is able to read other types of chunks than the ones handled by LodePNG,
1238
then that's possible with the chunk functions of LodePNG.
1239
A PNG chunk has the following layout:
1240
4 bytes length
1241
4 bytes type name
1242
length bytes data
1243
4 bytes CRC
1244
8.1. iterating through chunks
1245
-----------------------------
1246
If you have a buffer containing the PNG image data, then the first chunk (the
1247
IHDR chunk) starts at byte number 8 of that buffer. The first 8 bytes are the
1248
signature of the PNG and are not part of a chunk. But if you start at byte 8
1249
then you have a chunk, and can check the following things of it.
1250
NOTE: none of these functions check for memory buffer boundaries. To avoid
1251
exploits, always make sure the buffer contains all the data of the chunks.
1252
When using lodepng_chunk_next, make sure the returned value is within the
1253
allocated memory.
1254
unsigned lodepng_chunk_length(const unsigned char* chunk):
1255
Get the length of the chunk's data. The total chunk length is this length + 12.
1256
void lodepng_chunk_type(char type[5], const unsigned char* chunk):
1257
unsigned char lodepng_chunk_type_equals(const unsigned char* chunk, const char* type):
1258
Get the type of the chunk or compare if it's a certain type
1259
unsigned char lodepng_chunk_critical(const unsigned char* chunk):
1260
unsigned char lodepng_chunk_private(const unsigned char* chunk):
1261
unsigned char lodepng_chunk_safetocopy(const unsigned char* chunk):
1262
Check if the chunk is critical in the PNG standard (only IHDR, PLTE, IDAT and IEND are).
1263
Check if the chunk is private (public chunks are part of the standard, private ones not).
1264
Check if the chunk is safe to copy. If it's not, then, when modifying data in a critical
1265
chunk, unsafe to copy chunks of the old image may NOT be saved in the new one if your
1266
program doesn't handle that type of unknown chunk.
1267
unsigned char* lodepng_chunk_data(unsigned char* chunk):
1268
const unsigned char* lodepng_chunk_data_const(const unsigned char* chunk):
1269
Get a pointer to the start of the data of the chunk.
1270
unsigned lodepng_chunk_check_crc(const unsigned char* chunk):
1271
void lodepng_chunk_generate_crc(unsigned char* chunk):
1272
Check if the crc is correct or generate a correct one.
1273
unsigned char* lodepng_chunk_next(unsigned char* chunk):
1274
const unsigned char* lodepng_chunk_next_const(const unsigned char* chunk):
1275
Iterate to the next chunk. This works if you have a buffer with consecutive chunks. Note that these
1276
functions do no boundary checking of the allocated data whatsoever, so make sure there is enough
1277
data available in the buffer to be able to go to the next chunk.
1278
unsigned lodepng_chunk_append(unsigned char** out, size_t* outlength, const unsigned char* chunk):
1279
unsigned lodepng_chunk_create(unsigned char** out, size_t* outlength, unsigned length,
1280
                              const char* type, const unsigned char* data):
1281
These functions are used to create new chunks that are appended to the data in *out that has
1282
length *outlength. The append function appends an existing chunk to the new data. The create
1283
function creates a new chunk with the given parameters and appends it. Type is the 4-letter
1284
name of the chunk.
1285
8.2. chunks in info_png
1286
-----------------------
1287
The LodePNGInfo struct contains fields with the unknown chunk in it. It has 3
1288
buffers (each with size) to contain 3 types of unknown chunks:
1289
the ones that come before the PLTE chunk, the ones that come between the PLTE
1290
and the IDAT chunks, and the ones that come after the IDAT chunks.
1291
It's necessary to make the distionction between these 3 cases because the PNG
1292
standard forces to keep the ordering of unknown chunks compared to the critical
1293
chunks, but does not force any other ordering rules.
1294
info_png.unknown_chunks_data[0] is the chunks before PLTE
1295
info_png.unknown_chunks_data[1] is the chunks after PLTE, before IDAT
1296
info_png.unknown_chunks_data[2] is the chunks after IDAT
1297
The chunks in these 3 buffers can be iterated through and read by using the same
1298
way described in the previous subchapter.
1299
When using the decoder to decode a PNG, you can make it store all unknown chunks
1300
if you set the option settings.remember_unknown_chunks to 1. By default, this
1301
option is off (0).
1302
The encoder will always encode unknown chunks that are stored in the info_png.
1303
If you need it to add a particular chunk that isn't known by LodePNG, you can
1304
use lodepng_chunk_append or lodepng_chunk_create to the chunk data in
1305
info_png.unknown_chunks_data[x].
1306
Chunks that are known by LodePNG should not be added in that way. E.g. to make
1307
LodePNG add a bKGD chunk, set background_defined to true and add the correct
1308
parameters there instead.
1309
9. compiler support
1310
-------------------
1311
No libraries other than the current standard C library are needed to compile
1312
LodePNG. For the C++ version, only the standard C++ library is needed on top.
1313
Add the files lodepng.c(pp) and lodepng.h to your project, include
1314
lodepng.h where needed, and your program can read/write PNG files.
1315
It is compatible with C90 and up, and C++03 and up.
1316
If performance is important, use optimization when compiling! For both the
1317
encoder and decoder, this makes a large difference.
1318
Make sure that LodePNG is compiled with the same compiler of the same version
1319
and with the same settings as the rest of the program, or the interfaces with
1320
std::vectors and std::strings in C++ can be incompatible.
1321
CHAR_BITS must be 8 or higher, because LodePNG uses unsigned chars for octets.
1322
*) gcc and g++
1323
LodePNG is developed in gcc so this compiler is natively supported. It gives no
1324
warnings with compiler options "-Wall -Wextra -pedantic -ansi", with gcc and g++
1325
version 4.7.1 on Linux, 32-bit and 64-bit.
1326
*) Clang
1327
Fully supported and warning-free.
1328
*) Mingw
1329
The Mingw compiler (a port of gcc for Windows) should be fully supported by
1330
LodePNG.
1331
*) Visual Studio and Visual C++ Express Edition
1332
LodePNG should be warning-free with warning level W4. Two warnings were disabled
1333
with pragmas though: warning 4244 about implicit conversions, and warning 4996
1334
where it wants to use a non-standard function fopen_s instead of the standard C
1335
fopen.
1336
Visual Studio may want "stdafx.h" files to be included in each source file and
1337
give an error "unexpected end of file while looking for precompiled header".
1338
This is not standard C++ and will not be added to the stock LodePNG. You can
1339
disable it for lodepng.cpp only by right clicking it, Properties, C/C++,
1340
Precompiled Headers, and set it to Not Using Precompiled Headers there.
1341
NOTE: Modern versions of VS should be fully supported, but old versions, e.g.
1342
VS6, are not guaranteed to work.
1343
*) Compilers on Macintosh
1344
LodePNG has been reported to work both with gcc and LLVM for Macintosh, both for
1345
C and C++.
1346
*) Other Compilers
1347
If you encounter problems on any compilers, feel free to let me know and I may
1348
try to fix it if the compiler is modern and standards complient.
1349
10. examples
1350
------------
1351
This decoder example shows the most basic usage of LodePNG. More complex
1352
examples can be found on the LodePNG website.
1353
10.1. decoder C++ example
1354
-------------------------
1355
#include "lodepng.h"
1356
#include <iostream>
1357
int main(int argc, char *argv[])
1358
{
1359
  const char* filename = argc > 1 ? argv[1] : "test.png";
1360
  //load and decode
1361
  std::vector<unsigned char> image;
1362
  unsigned width, height;
1363
  unsigned error = lodepng::decode(image, width, height, filename);
1364
  //if there's an error, display it
1365
  if(error) std::cout << "decoder error " << error << ": " << lodepng_error_text(error) << std::endl;
1366
  //the pixels are now in the vector "image", 4 bytes per pixel, ordered RGBARGBA..., use it as texture, draw it, ...
1367
}
1368
10.2. decoder C example
1369
-----------------------
1370
#include "lodepng.h"
1371
int main(int argc, char *argv[])
1372
{
1373
  unsigned error;
1374
  unsigned char* image;
1375
  size_t width, height;
1376
  const char* filename = argc > 1 ? argv[1] : "test.png";
1377
  error = lodepng_decode32_file(&image, &width, &height, filename);
1378
  if(error) printf("decoder error %u: %s\n", error, lodepng_error_text(error));
1379
  / * use image here * /
1380
  free(image);
1381
  return 0;
1382
}
1383
11. state settings reference
1384
----------------------------
1385
A quick reference of some settings to set on the LodePNGState
1386
For decoding:
1387
state.decoder.zlibsettings.ignore_adler32: ignore ADLER32 checksums
1388
state.decoder.zlibsettings.custom_...: use custom inflate function
1389
state.decoder.ignore_crc: ignore CRC checksums
1390
state.decoder.color_convert: convert internal PNG color to chosen one
1391
state.decoder.read_text_chunks: whether to read in text metadata chunks
1392
state.decoder.remember_unknown_chunks: whether to read in unknown chunks
1393
state.info_raw.colortype: desired color type for decoded image
1394
state.info_raw.bitdepth: desired bit depth for decoded image
1395
state.info_raw....: more color settings, see struct LodePNGColorMode
1396
state.info_png....: no settings for decoder but ouput, see struct LodePNGInfo
1397
For encoding:
1398
state.encoder.zlibsettings.btype: disable compression by setting it to 0
1399
state.encoder.zlibsettings.use_lz77: use LZ77 in compression
1400
state.encoder.zlibsettings.windowsize: tweak LZ77 windowsize
1401
state.encoder.zlibsettings.minmatch: tweak min LZ77 length to match
1402
state.encoder.zlibsettings.nicematch: tweak LZ77 match where to stop searching
1403
state.encoder.zlibsettings.lazymatching: try one more LZ77 matching
1404
state.encoder.zlibsettings.custom_...: use custom deflate function
1405
state.encoder.auto_convert: choose optimal PNG color type, if 0 uses info_png
1406
state.encoder.filter_palette_zero: PNG filter strategy for palette
1407
state.encoder.filter_strategy: PNG filter strategy to encode with
1408
state.encoder.force_palette: add palette even if not encoding to one
1409
state.encoder.add_id: add LodePNG identifier and version as a text chunk
1410
state.encoder.text_compression: use compressed text chunks for metadata
1411
state.info_raw.colortype: color type of raw input image you provide
1412
state.info_raw.bitdepth: bit depth of raw input image you provide
1413
state.info_raw: more color settings, see struct LodePNGColorMode
1414
state.info_png.color.colortype: desired color type if auto_convert is false
1415
state.info_png.color.bitdepth: desired bit depth if auto_convert is false
1416
state.info_png.color....: more color settings, see struct LodePNGColorMode
1417
state.info_png....: more PNG related settings, see struct LodePNGInfo
1418
12. changes
1419
-----------
1420
The version number of LodePNG is the date of the change given in the format
1421
yyyymmdd.
1422
Some changes aren't backwards compatible. Those are indicated with a (!)
1423
symbol.
1424
*) 27 nov 2016: grey+alpha auto color model detection bugfix
1425
*) 18 apr 2016: Changed qsort to custom stable sort (for platforms w/o qsort).
1426
*) 09 apr 2016: Fixed colorkey usage detection, and better file loading (within
1427
   the limits of pure C90).
1428
*) 08 dec 2015: Made load_file function return error if file can't be opened.
1429
*) 24 okt 2015: Bugfix with decoding to palette output.
1430
*) 18 apr 2015: Boundary PM instead of just package-merge for faster encoding.
1431
*) 23 aug 2014: Reduced needless memory usage of decoder.
1432
*) 28 jun 2014: Removed fix_png setting, always support palette OOB for
1433
    simplicity. Made ColorProfile public.
1434
*) 09 jun 2014: Faster encoder by fixing hash bug and more zeros optimization.
1435
*) 22 dec 2013: Power of two windowsize required for optimization.
1436
*) 15 apr 2013: Fixed bug with LAC_ALPHA and color key.
1437
*) 25 mar 2013: Added an optional feature to ignore some PNG errors (fix_png).
1438
*) 11 mar 2013 (!): Bugfix with custom free. Changed from "my" to "lodepng_"
1439
    prefix for the custom allocators and made it possible with a new #define to
1440
    use custom ones in your project without needing to change lodepng's code.
1441
*) 28 jan 2013: Bugfix with color key.
1442
*) 27 okt 2012: Tweaks in text chunk keyword length error handling.
1443
*) 8 okt 2012 (!): Added new filter strategy (entropy) and new auto color mode.
1444
    (no palette). Better deflate tree encoding. New compression tweak settings.
1445
    Faster color conversions while decoding. Some internal cleanups.
1446
*) 23 sep 2012: Reduced warnings in Visual Studio a little bit.
1447
*) 1 sep 2012 (!): Removed #define's for giving custom (de)compression functions
1448
    and made it work with function pointers instead.
1449
*) 23 jun 2012: Added more filter strategies. Made it easier to use custom alloc
1450
    and free functions and toggle #defines from compiler flags. Small fixes.
1451
*) 6 may 2012 (!): Made plugging in custom zlib/deflate functions more flexible.
1452
*) 22 apr 2012 (!): Made interface more consistent, renaming a lot. Removed
1453
    redundant C++ codec classes. Reduced amount of structs. Everything changed,
1454
    but it is cleaner now imho and functionality remains the same. Also fixed
1455
    several bugs and shrunk the implementation code. Made new samples.
1456
*) 6 nov 2011 (!): By default, the encoder now automatically chooses the best
1457
    PNG color model and bit depth, based on the amount and type of colors of the
1458
    raw image. For this, autoLeaveOutAlphaChannel replaced by auto_choose_color.
1459
*) 9 okt 2011: simpler hash chain implementation for the encoder.
1460
*) 8 sep 2011: lz77 encoder lazy matching instead of greedy matching.
1461
*) 23 aug 2011: tweaked the zlib compression parameters after benchmarking.
1462
    A bug with the PNG filtertype heuristic was fixed, so that it chooses much
1463
    better ones (it's quite significant). A setting to do an experimental, slow,
1464
    brute force search for PNG filter types is added.
1465
*) 17 aug 2011 (!): changed some C zlib related function names.
1466
*) 16 aug 2011: made the code less wide (max 120 characters per line).
1467
*) 17 apr 2011: code cleanup. Bugfixes. Convert low to 16-bit per sample colors.
1468
*) 21 feb 2011: fixed compiling for C90. Fixed compiling with sections disabled.
1469
*) 11 dec 2010: encoding is made faster, based on suggestion by Peter Eastman
1470
    to optimize long sequences of zeros.
1471
*) 13 nov 2010: added LodePNG_InfoColor_hasPaletteAlpha and
1472
    LodePNG_InfoColor_canHaveAlpha functions for convenience.
1473
*) 7 nov 2010: added LodePNG_error_text function to get error code description.
1474
*) 30 okt 2010: made decoding slightly faster
1475
*) 26 okt 2010: (!) changed some C function and struct names (more consistent).
1476
     Reorganized the documentation and the declaration order in the header.
1477
*) 08 aug 2010: only changed some comments and external samples.
1478
*) 05 jul 2010: fixed bug thanks to warnings in the new gcc version.
1479
*) 14 mar 2010: fixed bug where too much memory was allocated for char buffers.
1480
*) 02 sep 2008: fixed bug where it could create empty tree that linux apps could
1481
    read by ignoring the problem but windows apps couldn't.
1482
*) 06 jun 2008: added more error checks for out of memory cases.
1483
*) 26 apr 2008: added a few more checks here and there to ensure more safety.
1484
*) 06 mar 2008: crash with encoding of strings fixed
1485
*) 02 feb 2008: support for international text chunks added (iTXt)
1486
*) 23 jan 2008: small cleanups, and #defines to divide code in sections
1487
*) 20 jan 2008: support for unknown chunks allowing using LodePNG for an editor.
1488
*) 18 jan 2008: support for tIME and pHYs chunks added to encoder and decoder.
1489
*) 17 jan 2008: ability to encode and decode compressed zTXt chunks added
1490
    Also various fixes, such as in the deflate and the padding bits code.
1491
*) 13 jan 2008: Added ability to encode Adam7-interlaced images. Improved
1492
    filtering code of encoder.
1493
*) 07 jan 2008: (!) changed LodePNG to use ISO C90 instead of C++. A
1494
    C++ wrapper around this provides an interface almost identical to before.
1495
    Having LodePNG be pure ISO C90 makes it more portable. The C and C++ code
1496
    are together in these files but it works both for C and C++ compilers.
1497
*) 29 dec 2007: (!) changed most integer types to unsigned int + other tweaks
1498
*) 30 aug 2007: bug fixed which makes this Borland C++ compatible
1499
*) 09 aug 2007: some VS2005 warnings removed again
1500
*) 21 jul 2007: deflate code placed in new namespace separate from zlib code
1501
*) 08 jun 2007: fixed bug with 2- and 4-bit color, and small interlaced images
1502
*) 04 jun 2007: improved support for Visual Studio 2005: crash with accessing
1503
    invalid std::vector element [0] fixed, and level 3 and 4 warnings removed
1504
*) 02 jun 2007: made the encoder add a tag with version by default
1505
*) 27 may 2007: zlib and png code separated (but still in the same file),
1506
    simple encoder/decoder functions added for more simple usage cases
1507
*) 19 may 2007: minor fixes, some code cleaning, new error added (error 69),
1508
    moved some examples from here to lodepng_examples.cpp
1509
*) 12 may 2007: palette decoding bug fixed
1510
*) 24 apr 2007: changed the license from BSD to the zlib license
1511
*) 11 mar 2007: very simple addition: ability to encode bKGD chunks.
1512
*) 04 mar 2007: (!) tEXt chunk related fixes, and support for encoding
1513
    palettized PNG images. Plus little interface change with palette and texts.
1514
*) 03 mar 2007: Made it encode dynamic Huffman shorter with repeat codes.
1515
    Fixed a bug where the end code of a block had length 0 in the Huffman tree.
1516
*) 26 feb 2007: Huffman compression with dynamic trees (BTYPE 2) now implemented
1517
    and supported by the encoder, resulting in smaller PNGs at the output.
1518
*) 27 jan 2007: Made the Adler-32 test faster so that a timewaste is gone.
1519
*) 24 jan 2007: gave encoder an error interface. Added color conversion from any
1520
    greyscale type to 8-bit greyscale with or without alpha.
1521
*) 21 jan 2007: (!) Totally changed the interface. It allows more color types
1522
    to convert to and is more uniform. See the manual for how it works now.
1523
*) 07 jan 2007: Some cleanup & fixes, and a few changes over the last days:
1524
    encode/decode custom tEXt chunks, separate classes for zlib & deflate, and
1525
    at last made the decoder give errors for incorrect Adler32 or Crc.
1526
*) 01 jan 2007: Fixed bug with encoding PNGs with less than 8 bits per channel.
1527
*) 29 dec 2006: Added support for encoding images without alpha channel, and
1528
    cleaned out code as well as making certain parts faster.
1529
*) 28 dec 2006: Added "Settings" to the encoder.
1530
*) 26 dec 2006: The encoder now does LZ77 encoding and produces much smaller files now.
1531
    Removed some code duplication in the decoder. Fixed little bug in an example.
1532
*) 09 dec 2006: (!) Placed output parameters of public functions as first parameter.
1533
    Fixed a bug of the decoder with 16-bit per color.
1534
*) 15 okt 2006: Changed documentation structure
1535
*) 09 okt 2006: Encoder class added. It encodes a valid PNG image from the
1536
    given image buffer, however for now it's not compressed.
1537
*) 08 sep 2006: (!) Changed to interface with a Decoder class
1538
*) 30 jul 2006: (!) LodePNG_InfoPng , width and height are now retrieved in different
1539
    way. Renamed decodePNG to decodePNGGeneric.
1540
*) 29 jul 2006: (!) Changed the interface: image info is now returned as a
1541
    struct of type LodePNG::LodePNG_Info, instead of a vector, which was a bit clumsy.
1542
*) 28 jul 2006: Cleaned the code and added new error checks.
1543
    Corrected terminology "deflate" into "inflate".
1544
*) 23 jun 2006: Added SDL example in the documentation in the header, this
1545
    example allows easy debugging by displaying the PNG and its transparency.
1546
*) 22 jun 2006: (!) Changed way to obtain error value. Added
1547
    loadFile function for convenience. Made decodePNG32 faster.
1548
*) 21 jun 2006: (!) Changed type of info vector to unsigned.
1549
    Changed position of palette in info vector. Fixed an important bug that
1550
    happened on PNGs with an uncompressed block.
1551
*) 16 jun 2006: Internally changed unsigned into unsigned where
1552
    needed, and performed some optimizations.
1553
*) 07 jun 2006: (!) Renamed functions to decodePNG and placed them
1554
    in LodePNG namespace. Changed the order of the parameters. Rewrote the
1555
    documentation in the header. Renamed files to lodepng.cpp and lodepng.h
1556
*) 22 apr 2006: Optimized and improved some code
1557
*) 07 sep 2005: (!) Changed to std::vector interface
1558
*) 12 aug 2005: Initial release (C++, decoder only)
1559
13. contact information
1560
-----------------------
1561
Feel free to contact me with suggestions, problems, comments, ... concerning
1562
LodePNG. If you encounter a PNG image that doesn't work properly with this
1563
decoder, feel free to send it and I'll use it to find and fix the problem.
1564
My email address is (puzzle the account and domain together with an @ symbol):
1565

// Returns a score determining if the pixel is an edge
23
// requires 1 <= x < width - 1; 1 <= y < height - 1
24

double edgeScore(PNG* im, unsigned x, unsigned y) {
25
600k
    double score = 0;
26
600k
       
27
600k
    // calculate score based on the luminance of the curret pixel
28
600k

29
2.40M
    for (int i = -1; i < 2; i++){
30
7.20M
        for (int j = -1; j < 2; j++){

void sketchify(std::string inputFile, std::string outputFile) {
44
2
    // Load in.png
45
2
    PNG* original = new PNG(); // initally nullptr
46
2
    original->readFromFile(inputFile);
47
2
    unsigned width = original->width();
48
2

49
2
    // Create out.png
50
2
    PNG* output = setupOutput(width, height);
51
2
52
2
    // Load our favorite color to color the outline
53
2
    HSLAPixel* myPixel = myFavoriteColor(0.5);
54
2
55
2
    // Go over the whole image, and if a pixel is likely to be an edge,
56

57
850
    for (unsigned y = 1; y < height; y++) {
58
601k
        for (unsigned x = 1; x < width; x++) {

            cout << "loop start" << endl;
60
600k
            // calculate how "edge-like" a pixel is
61
600k

62
600k
63
600k
            HSLAPixel* currOutPixel = output->getPixel(x, y);
64
600k

65

66
600k
